name: nu-ansi-term

readme.raw_markdown:
[](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/all.html "show sidebar")
# Crate nu_ansi_termCopy item path
[Settings](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/settings.html)
[Help](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/help.html)
Summary[Source](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/src/nu_ansi_term/lib.rs.html#1-267)
Expand description
This is a library for controlling colors and formatting, such as red bold text or blue underlined text, on ANSI terminals.
### [§](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/#basic-usage)Basic usage
There are three main types in this crate that you need to be concerned with: [`AnsiString`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/type.AnsiString.html), [`Style`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.Style.html), and [`Color`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/enum.Color.html).
A `Style` holds stylistic information: foreground and background colors, whether the text should be bold, or blinking, or other properties. The [`Color`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/enum.Color.html) enum represents the available colors. And an [`AnsiString`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/type.AnsiString.html) is a string paired with a [`Style`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.Style.html).
[`Color`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/enum.Color.html) is also available as an alias to `Color`.
To format a string, call the `paint` method on a `Style` or a `Color`, passing in the string you want to format as the argument. For example, here’s how to get some red text:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Color::Red;
println!("This is in red: {}", Red.paint("a red string"));
```

It’s important to note that the `paint` method does _not_ actually return a string with the ANSI control characters surrounding it. Instead, it returns an [`AnsiString`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/type.AnsiString.html) value that has a [`Display`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/fmt/trait.Display.html) implementation that, when formatted, returns the characters. This allows strings to be printed with a minimum of [`String`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/string/struct.String.html) allocations being performed behind the scenes.
If you _do_ want to get at the escape codes, then you can convert the [`AnsiString`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/type.AnsiString.html) to a string as you would any other `Display` value:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Color::Red;
let red_string = Red.paint("a red string").to_string();
```

### [§](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/#bold-underline-background-and-other-styles)Bold, underline, background, and other styles
For anything more complex than plain foreground color changes, you need to construct `Style` values themselves, rather than beginning with a `Color`. You can do this by chaining methods based on a new `Style`, created with [`Style::new()`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.Style.html#method.new). Each method creates a new style that has that specific property set. For example:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Style;
println!("How about some {} and {}?",
     Style::new().bold().paint("bold"),
     Style::new().underline().paint("underline"));
```

For brevity, these methods have also been implemented for `Color` values, so you can give your styles a foreground color without having to begin with an empty `Style` value:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Color::{Blue, Yellow};
println!("Demonstrating {} and {}!",
     Blue.bold().paint("blue bold"),
     Yellow.underline().paint("yellow underline"));
println!("Yellow on blue: {}", Yellow.on(Blue).paint("wow!"));
```

The complete list of styles you can use are: [`bold`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.Style.html#method.bold), [`dimmed`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.Style.html#method.dimmed), [`italic`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.Style.html#method.italic), [`underline`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.Style.html#method.underline), [`blink`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.Style.html#method.blink), [`reverse`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.Style.html#method.reverse), [`hidden`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.Style.html#method.hidden), [`strikethrough`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.Style.html#method.strikethrough), and [`on`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.Style.html#method.on) for background colors.
In some cases, you may find it easier to change the foreground on an existing `Style` rather than starting from the appropriate `Color`. You can do this using the [`fg`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.Style.html#method.fg) method:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Style;
use nu_ansi_term::Color::{Blue, Cyan, Yellow};
println!("Yellow on blue: {}", Style::new().on(Blue).fg(Yellow).paint("yow!"));
println!("Also yellow on blue: {}", Cyan.on(Blue).fg(Yellow).paint("zow!"));
```

You can turn a `Color` into a `Style` with the [`normal`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/enum.Color.html#method.normal) method. This will produce the exact same `AnsiString` as if you just used the `paint` method on the `Color` directly, but it’s useful in certain cases: for example, you may have a method that returns `Styles`, and need to represent both the “red bold” and “red, but not bold” styles with values of the same type. The `Style` struct also has a [`Default`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/default/trait.Default.html) implementation if you want to have a style with _nothing_ set.
```
use nu_ansi_term::Style;
use nu_ansi_term::Color::Red;
Red.normal().paint("yet another red string");
Style::default().paint("a completely regular string");
```

### [§](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/#extended-colors)Extended colors
You can access the extended range of 256 colors by using the `Color::Fixed` variant, which takes an argument of the color number to use. This can be included wherever you would use a `Color`:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Color::Fixed;
Fixed(134).paint("A sort of light purple");
Fixed(221).on(Fixed(124)).paint("Mustard in the ketchup");
```

The first sixteen of these values are the same as the normal and bold standard color variants. There’s nothing stopping you from using these as `Fixed` colors instead, but there’s nothing to be gained by doing so either.
You can also access full 24-bit color by using the `Color::Rgb` variant, which takes separate `u8` arguments for red, green, and blue:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Color::Rgb;
Rgb(70, 130, 180).paint("Steel blue");
```

### [§](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/#combining-successive-colored-strings)Combining successive colored strings
The benefit of writing ANSI escape codes to the terminal is that they _stack_ : you do not need to end every colored string with a reset code if the text that follows it is of a similar style. For example, if you want to have some blue text followed by some blue bold text, it’s possible to send the ANSI code for blue, followed by the ANSI code for bold, and finishing with a reset code without having to have an extra one between the two strings.
This crate can optimise the ANSI codes that get printed in situations like this, making life easier for your terminal renderer. The [`AnsiStrings`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/type.AnsiStrings.html) type takes a slice of several [`AnsiString`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/type.AnsiString.html) values, and will iterate over each of them, printing only the codes for the styles that need to be updated as part of its formatting routine.
The following code snippet uses this to enclose a binary number displayed in red bold text inside some red, but not bold, brackets:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Color::Red;
use nu_ansi_term::{AnsiString, AnsiStrings};
let some_value = format!("{:b}", 42);
let strings: &[AnsiString<'static>] = &[
  Red.paint("["),
  Red.bold().paint(some_value),
  Red.paint("]"),
];
println!("Value: {}", AnsiStrings(strings));
```

There are several things to note here. Firstly, the [`paint`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/type.AnsiByteString.html#method.write_to) method can take _either_ an owned [`String`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/string/struct.String.html) or a borrowed [`&str`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.str.html). Internally, an [`AnsiString`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/type.AnsiString.html) holds a copy-on-write ([`Cow`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/borrow/enum.Cow.html)) string value to deal with both owned and borrowed strings at the same time. This is used here to display a `String`, the result of the `format!` call, using the same mechanism as some statically-available `&str` slices. Secondly, that the [`AnsiStrings`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/type.AnsiStrings.html) value works in the same way as its singular counterpart, with a [`Display`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/fmt/trait.Display.html) implementation that only performs the formatting when required.
### [§](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/#byte-strings)Byte strings
This library also supports formatting `\[u8]` byte strings; this supports applications working with text in an unknown encoding. [`Style`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.Style.html) and [`Color`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/enum.Color.html) support painting `\[u8]` values, resulting in an [`AnsiByteString`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/type.AnsiByteString.html). This type does not implement [`Display`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/fmt/trait.Display.html), as it may not contain UTF-8, but it does provide a method [`write_to`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/type.AnsiByteString.html#method.write_to) to write the result to any value that implements [`Write`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/io/trait.Write.html):
```
use nu_ansi_term::Color::Green;
Green.paint("user data".as_bytes()).write_to(&mut std::io::stdout()).unwrap();
```

Similarly, the type [`AnsiByteStrings`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/type.AnsiByteStrings.html) supports writing a list of [`AnsiByteString`](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/type.AnsiByteString.html) values with minimal escape sequences:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Color::Green;
use nu_ansi_term::AnsiByteStrings;
AnsiByteStrings(&[
  Green.paint("user data 1\n".as_bytes()),
  Green.bold().paint("user data 2\n".as_bytes()),
]).write_to(&mut std::io::stdout()).unwrap();
```

## Re-exports[§](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/#reexports)

`pub use ansi::Infix[](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/ansi/struct.Infix.html "struct nu_ansi_term::ansi::Infix");`


`pub use ansi::Prefix[](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/ansi/struct.Prefix.html "struct nu_ansi_term::ansi::Prefix");`


`pub use ansi::Suffix[](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/ansi/struct.Suffix.html "struct nu_ansi_term::ansi::Suffix");`


`pub use gradient[](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/gradient/index.html "mod nu_ansi_term::gradient")::*;`

## Modules[§](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/#modules)

[ansi](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/ansi/index.html "mod nu_ansi_term::ansi")


[gradient](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/gradient/index.html "mod nu_ansi_term::gradient")

## Structs[§](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/#structs)

[AnsiGenericString](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.AnsiGenericString.html "struct nu_ansi_term::AnsiGenericString")
    An `AnsiGenericString` includes a generic string type and a `Style` to display that string. `AnsiString` and `AnsiByteString` are aliases for this type on `str` and `\[u8]`, respectively.

[AnsiGenericStrings](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.AnsiGenericStrings.html "struct nu_ansi_term::AnsiGenericStrings")
    A set of `AnsiGenericStrings`s collected together, in order to be written with a minimum of control characters.

[Rgb](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.Rgb.html "struct nu_ansi_term::Rgb")


[Style](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/struct.Style.html "struct nu_ansi_term::Style")
    A style is a collection of properties that can format a string using ANSI escape codes.
## Enums[§](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/#enums)

[Color](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/enum.Color.html "enum nu_ansi_term::Color")
    A color is one specific type of ANSI escape code, and can refer to either the foreground or background color.
## Functions[§](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/#functions)

[AnsiByteStrings](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/fn.AnsiByteStrings.html "fn nu_ansi_term::AnsiByteStrings")
    A function to construct an `AnsiByteStrings` instance.

[AnsiStrings](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/fn.AnsiStrings.html "fn nu_ansi_term::AnsiStrings")
    A function to construct an `AnsiStrings` instance.

[sub_string](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/fn.sub_string.html "fn nu_ansi_term::sub_string")
    Return a substring of the given AnsiStrings sequence, while keeping the formatting.

[unstyle](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/fn.unstyle.html "fn nu_ansi_term::unstyle")
    Return a concatenated copy of `strs` without the formatting, as an allocated `String`.

[unstyled_len](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/fn.unstyled_len.html "fn nu_ansi_term::unstyled_len")
    Return the unstyled length of AnsiStrings. This is equaivalent to `unstyle(strs).len()`.
## Type Aliases[§](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/#types)

[AnsiByteString](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/type.AnsiByteString.html "type nu_ansi_term::AnsiByteString")
    An `AnsiByteString` represents a formatted series of bytes. Use `AnsiByteString` when styling text with an unknown encoding.

[AnsiByteStrings](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/type.AnsiByteStrings.html "type nu_ansi_term::AnsiByteStrings")
    A set of `AnsiByteString`s collected together, in order to be written with a minimum of control characters.

[AnsiString](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/type.AnsiString.html "type nu_ansi_term::AnsiString")
    An ANSI String is a string coupled with the `Style` to display it in a terminal.

[AnsiStrings](https://docs.rs/nu-ansi-term/latest/nu_ansi_term/type.AnsiStrings.html "type nu_ansi_term::AnsiStrings")
    A set of `AnsiString`s collected together, in order to be written with a minimum of control characters.

# Crate nu_ansi_termCopy item path

Expand description
This is a library for controlling colors and formatting, such as red bold text or blue underlined text, on ANSI terminals.
### §⟨4⟩Basic usage
There are three main types in this crate that you need to be concerned with: `AnsiString`⟨5⟩, `Style`⟨6⟩, and `Color`⟨7⟩.
A `Style` holds stylistic information: foreground and background colors, whether the text should be bold, or blinking, or other properties. The `Color`⟨7⟩ enum represents the available colors. And an `AnsiString`⟨5⟩ is a string paired with a `Style`⟨6⟩.
`Color`⟨7⟩ is also available as an alias to `Color`.
To format a string, call the `paint` method on a `Style` or a `Color`, passing in the string you want to format as the argument. For example, here’s how to get some red text:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Color::Red;
println!("This is in red: {}", Red.paint("a red string"));
```

It’s important to note that the `paint` method does _not_ actually return a string with the ANSI control characters surrounding it. Instead, it returns an `AnsiString`⟨5⟩ value that has a `Display`⟨8⟩ implementation that, when formatted, returns the characters. This allows strings to be printed with a minimum of `String`⟨9⟩ allocations being performed behind the scenes.
If you _do_ want to get at the escape codes, then you can convert the `AnsiString`⟨5⟩ to a string as you would any other `Display` value:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Color::Red;
let red_string = Red.paint("a red string").to_string();
```

### §⟨10⟩Bold, underline, background, and other styles
For anything more complex than plain foreground color changes, you need to construct `Style` values themselves, rather than beginning with a `Color`. You can do this by chaining methods based on a new `Style`, created with `Style::new()`⟨11⟩. Each method creates a new style that has that specific property set. For example:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Style;
println!("How about some {} and {}?",
     Style::new().bold().paint("bold"),
     Style::new().underline().paint("underline"));
```

For brevity, these methods have also been implemented for `Color` values, so you can give your styles a foreground color without having to begin with an empty `Style` value:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Color::{Blue, Yellow};
println!("Demonstrating {} and {}!",
     Blue.bold().paint("blue bold"),
     Yellow.underline().paint("yellow underline"));
println!("Yellow on blue: {}", Yellow.on(Blue).paint("wow!"));
```

The complete list of styles you can use are: `bold`⟨12⟩, `dimmed`⟨13⟩, `italic`⟨14⟩, `underline`⟨15⟩, `blink`⟨16⟩, `reverse`⟨17⟩, `hidden`⟨18⟩, `strikethrough`⟨19⟩, and `on`⟨20⟩ for background colors.
In some cases, you may find it easier to change the foreground on an existing `Style` rather than starting from the appropriate `Color`. You can do this using the `fg`⟨21⟩ method:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Style;
use nu_ansi_term::Color::{Blue, Cyan, Yellow};
println!("Yellow on blue: {}", Style::new().on(Blue).fg(Yellow).paint("yow!"));
println!("Also yellow on blue: {}", Cyan.on(Blue).fg(Yellow).paint("zow!"));
```

You can turn a `Color` into a `Style` with the `normal`⟨22⟩ method. This will produce the exact same `AnsiString` as if you just used the `paint` method on the `Color` directly, but it’s useful in certain cases: for example, you may have a method that returns `Styles`, and need to represent both the “red bold” and “red, but not bold” styles with values of the same type. The `Style` struct also has a `Default`⟨23⟩ implementation if you want to have a style with _nothing_ set.
```
use nu_ansi_term::Style;
use nu_ansi_term::Color::Red;
Red.normal().paint("yet another red string");
Style::default().paint("a completely regular string");
```

### §⟨24⟩Extended colors
You can access the extended range of 256 colors by using the `Color::Fixed` variant, which takes an argument of the color number to use. This can be included wherever you would use a `Color`:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Color::Fixed;
Fixed(134).paint("A sort of light purple");
Fixed(221).on(Fixed(124)).paint("Mustard in the ketchup");
```

The first sixteen of these values are the same as the normal and bold standard color variants. There’s nothing stopping you from using these as `Fixed` colors instead, but there’s nothing to be gained by doing so either.
You can also access full 24-bit color by using the `Color::Rgb` variant, which takes separate `u8` arguments for red, green, and blue:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Color::Rgb;
Rgb(70, 130, 180).paint("Steel blue");
```

### §⟨25⟩Combining successive colored strings
The benefit of writing ANSI escape codes to the terminal is that they _stack_ : you do not need to end every colored string with a reset code if the text that follows it is of a similar style. For example, if you want to have some blue text followed by some blue bold text, it’s possible to send the ANSI code for blue, followed by the ANSI code for bold, and finishing with a reset code without having to have an extra one between the two strings.
This crate can optimise the ANSI codes that get printed in situations like this, making life easier for your terminal renderer. The `AnsiStrings`⟨26⟩ type takes a slice of several `AnsiString`⟨5⟩ values, and will iterate over each of them, printing only the codes for the styles that need to be updated as part of its formatting routine.
The following code snippet uses this to enclose a binary number displayed in red bold text inside some red, but not bold, brackets:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Color::Red;
use nu_ansi_term::{AnsiString, AnsiStrings};
let some_value = format!("{:b}", 42);
let strings: &[AnsiString<'static>] = &[
  Red.paint("["),
  Red.bold().paint(some_value),
  Red.paint("]"),
];
println!("Value: {}", AnsiStrings(strings));
```

There are several things to note here. Firstly, the `paint`⟨27⟩ method can take _either_ an owned `String`⟨9⟩ or a borrowed `&str`⟨28⟩. Internally, an `AnsiString`⟨5⟩ holds a copy-on-write (`Cow`⟨29⟩) string value to deal with both owned and borrowed strings at the same time. This is used here to display a `String`, the result of the `format!` call, using the same mechanism as some statically-available `&str` slices. Secondly, that the `AnsiStrings`⟨26⟩ value works in the same way as its singular counterpart, with a `Display`⟨8⟩ implementation that only performs the formatting when required.
### §⟨30⟩Byte strings
This library also supports formatting `\[u8]` byte strings; this supports applications working with text in an unknown encoding. `Style`⟨6⟩ and `Color`⟨7⟩ support painting `\[u8]` values, resulting in an `AnsiByteString`⟨31⟩. This type does not implement `Display`⟨8⟩, as it may not contain UTF-8, but it does provide a method `write_to`⟨27⟩ to write the result to any value that implements `Write`⟨32⟩:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Color::Green;
Green.paint("user data".as_bytes()).write_to(&mut std::io::stdout()).unwrap();
```

Similarly, the type `AnsiByteStrings`⟨33⟩ supports writing a list of `AnsiByteString`⟨31⟩ values with minimal escape sequences:
```
use nu_ansi_term::Color::Green;
use nu_ansi_term::AnsiByteStrings;
AnsiByteStrings(&[
  Green.paint("user data 1\n".as_bytes()),
  Green.bold().paint("user data 2\n".as_bytes()),
]).write_to(&mut std::io::stdout()).unwrap();
```

sub_string⟨46⟩
    Return a substring of the given AnsiStrings sequence, while keeping the formatting.

unstyle⟨47⟩
    Return a concatenated copy of `strs` without the formatting, as an allocated `String`.

unstyled_len⟨48⟩
    Return the unstyled length of AnsiStrings. This is equaivalent to `unstyle(strs).len()`.
## Type Aliases§⟨49⟩

AnsiByteString⟨31⟩
    An `AnsiByteString` represents a formatted series of bytes. Use `AnsiByteString` when styling text with an unknown encoding.

AnsiByteStrings⟨33⟩
    A set of `AnsiByteString`s collected together, in order to be written with a minimum of control characters.

AnsiString⟨5⟩
    An ANSI String is a string coupled with the `Style` to display it in a terminal.

AnsiStrings⟨26⟩
    A set of `AnsiString`s collected together, in order to be written with a minimum of control characters.

readme_summary: The `nu-ansi-term` crate provides utilities for styling and formatting text with ANSI escape codes in terminal applications, supporting features like foreground and background colors, bold, underline, and other text styles. It offers extended 256-color and 24-bit RGB support, efficient handling of successive styled strings, and compatibility with both UTF-8 and byte strings. Key types include `Style`, `Color`, `AnsiString`, and `AnsiByteString`, enabling flexible and optimized text rendering.
factual_counterfactual:
### Pair 1: Basic Usage  
✅ **Factual:** The `paint` method in the `nu-ansi-term` crate returns an `AnsiString` that implements the `Display` trait, allowing formatted text to be printed directly without additional string allocations.  
❌ **Counterfactual:** The `paint` method directly returns a `String` containing ANSI escape codes, which can be used immediately for text output.  

---

### Pair 2: Extended Colors  
✅ **Factual:** The crate supports extended 256-color palettes using the `Color::Fixed` variant, and full 24-bit RGB color using the `Color::Rgb` variant.  
❌ **Counterfactual:** The crate only supports the standard 16 ANSI colors and does not provide access to extended or RGB color ranges.  

---

### Pair 3: Combining Styles  
✅ **Factual:** The `AnsiStrings` type in `nu-ansi-term` optimizes successive ANSI escape codes by printing only the necessary style updates, reducing redundant control characters.  
❌ **Counterfactual:** The `AnsiStrings` type concatenates all ANSI escape codes for each string in the sequence, leading to redundant control characters being printed.
